content.question:
A high school science teacher has 78 students. Of those students, 35 are in the band and 32 are on a sports team. There are 16 students who are not in the band or on a sports team. One student from the 78 students will be selected at random. Let event <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the event of selecting a student in the band, and let event <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the event of selecting a student on a sports team.
Are <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> mutually exclusive events?

choices.label: No, because <math alttext="the probability of, B intersection S, equals the fraction 5 over 78" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>78</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No, because <math alttext="the probability of, B intersection S, equals the fraction 48 over 78" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle><mfrac><mrow><mn>48</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>78</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No, because <math alttext="the probability of, B intersection S, equals the fraction 62 over 78" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle><mfrac><mrow><mn>62</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>78</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because <math alttext="the probability of, B intersection S, equals the fraction 5 over 78" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>78</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because <math alttext="the probability of, B intersection S, equals the fraction 62 over 78" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo></mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>62</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>78</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: No, because <math alttext="the probability of, B intersection S, equals the fraction 5 over 78" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>78</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

unit.text: 4: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
